poems.title: ten o'clock shouts
text: after the sun's long gone
and everybody makes their way home
a solitary voice calls out
香港人
the opening salvo
then
the pulse of anger and grief writ large
war cries echo in the canyons of skyscrapers
waves of sound that ripple cross space and time
prayers to gods in the stars above
do they fall upon deaf ears?
calls and responses
chant after chant
as myriad voices coalesce
into one
as escalations
and provocations
raise the bloods
to fever pitch
add oil
becomes
resist
becomes
avenge
the anthem rings out
out of the windows and balconies
a makeshift chorus assembles itself
glory be to thee, Hong Kong

poems.title: when a home breaks down
text: city split down the middle like a lightning strike.
what's mine is yours is ours is no one's.
the streets and the stop signs
are all stroking each other's flames.
we are
pushing
through a fog we can't breathe in.
stake to my heart, to my home -
this is not a Trojan war.
a wall is a concept, not a solution.
we all want
clear skies, winding roads that move.
we all want to fly free as birds,
a city with wings that have been clipped
right from the very start

poems.title: rebellion and the reason to be angry
text: to know that you were taking us for fools
infuriated more than insults made
by bad decisions. we kept to the rules
we understand the game and how it's played
to witness the abuse you threw our way
reflected deeds your people had performed!
it often not is the action, it's the lie
that makes the hate for men in uniform
affronted by abuses you commit
on fact and truth, the false reports we hear,
the chronic pain we get from hearing shit
will manifest in anger not in tears
our atmosphere and climate soon to change
complacency has now turned into rage

poems.title: mask
text: the mask I wear
I use to stop the gas from burning
my lungs, to stop
the bleeding rounds
that carry your violence
when pepper spray
becomes an everyday routine.
the mask I wear
I use to cover my tears from running
down my face of recognition;
a collective state
of a people, not singular
when at home
we are your sons and daughters.
the mask I wear
I wear it with honesty
and pride, that I
do not need
to cover my eyes
when I could look towards a future
where I followed my demands
that I do not have to wear a mask
to make your jobs easier
if you find us forced on bloody ground.
for the mask I wear
I wear to unmask
the guise of those who hide behind
the cameras that wear their faces;
the masks they wear
with Janus smiles,
those who turn a blind eye
and believe that everything falling is more than all right.

poems.title: the bystanders
text: Ⅰ
it’s strange how outwardly we thrive,
while beyond us something swells like
sea-wind on blackened, raging waves;
and strangled cries fight extractor fans and slow exhaling rice.
Ⅱ
it's strange how outwardly we're fine,
though resting minds want it darker.
darker things nudge the curtain,
things we’ve half a mind to explore: smash, burn,
shadows in a cave.
Ⅲ
it’s strange how we appear listless,
witnesses, rubbernecks; gawpers
entranced by pictures of the maimed.
We open the window, and gape at the
faceless racing by.
Ⅳ
it’s strange how we phone relatives
who say, ‘come home,’ but the word clots
because somewhere home became here—
then the blaze of shame: to be gone when they
round up the neighbours.
Ⅴ
it’s frightening how night-mind plays games:
Mad Max is visored, thickly clad;
and the angry smash signs, their crimes
because those that glare at them like stones are
too far and too high.
Ⅵ
It’s sad and strange how while we sleep,
the skies hum and glower until
morning. But by the time we awake,
it’s too late to tell the dispossessed who
clean up the mess,
thank you.

poems.title: capitalist hangover
text: with white face
and work visa
solidarity becomes
storage for
frontline kit
and silent embrace
as she repeats:
“there are so many things--
so much has happened--
I hate the cops.”
I’ll hold your bag
when you jump
the MTR gate
even the transfer
through East TST
point out where
there are no cameras
in Tin Hau
buy you an ice cream
as we’re home

poems.title: aggressive fruit
text: jets of blue
at five guys
bodies stacked
near papa johns
CS gas dispersing aside
a shuttered swarovski
the unruly mob
of jackboots
violence in the streets
emblazoned with the word
police
a luxury brand
MRAP
now idle an
impartial eye
hangs above
in LED
confetti for the crowd
just do it

poems.title: boiling frog
text: a million people took to the streets today
the rest seemed normal
protestors surrounded legco today
and the police fired teargas
the rest seemed normal
two million people took to the streets today
an empty apology not accepted
the rest seemed normal
protestors breached legco today
a flurry of action on the day of establishment
past nine, on all the streams
tuned to footage of the siege
for all the world to see
a man clad in black took off his mask
the rest seemed normal
the government took a step back today.
announcing the bill was 'dead'
buried in semantics
was the wisdom of the crowd
the rest seemed normal
the riot police charged forward today
raptors on the prowl
shopping mall's their hunting ground
preying on the passers-by
blood shed on the marble
the rest seemed normal
the triads came out to play today
armed with bloodlust and rattan bats
greeting people,
citizens,
reaching home station
with cuts,
bruises,
welts
the rest seemed normal
the city went on strike today
downtown left a void
absence a sign of presence
presence of a greater will
a sense of conviction growing stronger
the rest seemed normal
the space museum was lit today
stargazers crowded around the sphere by the harbour
armed with cheer and laser pointers
as a few danced with their shads
the rest seemed normal
the raptors stormed a train car today
little more than kids,
terrorized and pepper-sprayed
the rest seemed normal
one demand was met today
stocks "soar on hope of resolution"
the rest seemed normal
the police shot a student today.
a bullet, three centimetres from the heart
wound gushing
red
the rest seemed normal
a lot of people missed class today
a common refrain
boycott classes // not education
the instructor, with an emphathetic look
gave the day off
stay safe, they say
the rest seemed normal
the malls were filled with people today
chanting forth a revolution
they paraded around the mall
leaving post-its plastered on the walls
a circle sat on the floor in a public place
calling down the onlookers on the balconies
"it's always seems impossible until it's done"
the rest seemed normal
the mtr exits were on fire today
and all would be closed the whole day tomorrow
the rest seemed normal
my night classes were cancelled today.
the trains stopped running at six.
and the rest seems normal.

poems.title: day in the life of
text: you forget what fresh air tasted like
sweet oxygen that isn't clogged with terror, tear gas, and grief
to stroll down the food stalls and eat roadside snacks without worry
teenagers still in school uniforms go window shopping in the evening
small children running and laughing freely in the streets
I had a vacation that reminded me of Hong Kong - made me homesick for what home used to be
the atmosphere here chokes me everyday
I feel a constant clawing in my throat, begging to be coughed up in dead cells and bloodied particulates
this seeping sickness strangles my lymph nodes, blooms blisters on my feet
I wonder if one day it will silence my vocal chords completely
if they'll stuff words into my paralysed mouth, when I no longer have the means to defend my character
there's something in the water here
it makes the devout drinkers go rabid, see half-truths that aren't there
they replaced the reservoirs with a new kind of poison
it coils beneath our skin, triggers a slow extinction
no more waters flowing freely
no more laughter from loitering schoolchildren on the streets
there's dead fish in the harbour by the thousands
there's dying kids in detention centres by the hundreds
I have no illusions about my health
I'll be another statistic in the collateral damage
if it doesn't sink the real estate market, all else is dispensable
new settlers will settle this land
and bulldoze and build over our corpses for more capital flow
I saw all of this in China's well-built ghost towns
and that is why I must scream while I'm still breathing

poems.title: love and hate
text: there are two great forces that live together in the center of the human heart.
one is hate, the other is love.
this urge to rage against the other.
to cry out and charge and demand they burn, they lose, they suffer,
that they receive justice,
justice for our martyrs.
what is inside us to brandish principal like a bludgeon
and beat our way through our old promises for peace and redemption.
those old words we spoke so often when the hate was asleep.
those words that hate silenced.
we will not call it hate when we are right,
when we are right our hate is righteous, it is the fuel in our blood,
hate makes heroes of us all.
it is the place from which we damn each other,
our private courts of justice.
hate demands an enemy and an enemy demands hate.
it demands a villain.
a tyrant.
a cockroach.
a dog.
we never call it hate, this anger, this rage,
when we raise our voice to drown someone else out,
when we condemn an entire group, an entire race, an entire organisation
and forget that groups are made up of people.
of sisters and brothers
and fathers and mother
and sons and daughters
and lovers
and children.
reduced like us, to a mob. faceless,
masks placed over eyes
so we no longer have to stare at the human inside.
this hate has poisoned our home.
I’m not talking about any sides anymore,
I’m tired of sides, those sides are lies,
easy, complacent lies,
tribes.
I’m tired of tribes
but I’m not tired of hate because hatred is a flame,
it can burn for generations, it can raze entire cities,
torture, disgrace, denigrate,
the children are not spared by hate,
there are no bystanders in the great fight that hate fuels.
what an awesome force hate is.
and we meet hatred, with hatred.
we form into our groups and our clans
and our sides,
with our insignias and colors and uniforms.
we separate and declare war on one another.
I hear the hatred online,
like a digital warcry,
the pulpits are on Facebook and Twitter.
how many of us are guilty of hate?
of having blanket condemned the other side,
of disgust and forgetting people.
I am guilty of forgetting people.
I dare anyone with an ounce of humanity,
to look another in the eye, face to face, in an empty room and hate.
truly hate.
to stop screaming and just look.
to Ask a question.
realize how similar we are. not different.
I said there were two great powers in the human heart,
I wanted to say that love will find a way,
that love will overpower hate,
but today I am no longer sure.
because hate is louder and burns brighter.
whereas love is mostly quiet.
and necessary.
the warmth behind closed doors,
community and home,
love is often too private for its own good.
and maybe love never won a war.
maybe love never moved a nation.
maybe love doesn’t bring the cheers and whoops and clicks from the crowd.
I love because I remember pain.
and hate brings pain.
if you stopped and let yourself feel their pain.
realize that their hate that causes your pain,
has the same root cause,
that we hurt each other with
the same mistake, the same sin, the same joke.
if you let yourself hurt and do not hate back
and think: my god, this is how they feel as well,
this is how their children feel.
if you do not allow hate to scream,
if you take the incredible risk. And love despite it all,
if you step down and feel once again,
if you realize that you only hate because you love as well,
maybe we have a chance.
I would have the spring water of love flood over hate
and quench it with its sacred might.
I would have the silent who love and accept
raise their voices with the same passion as the angered.
I would have the ones who care for the ones left behind
stand arrayed on the front lines.
the rearguard step forward.
I would have the dreamers words echo once again,
the defiant battle cry of the merciful,
in the face of hatred,
the empathic in the midst of callousness,
the peaceful among the warlike,
the ones who dared to say that we are all the same,
regardless of color or creed, or age, or gender,
because we no longer draw our lines so clearly,
but the lines still remain
and those dreamers words are not always true,
not today.
I would have love stand, just for one day.
I believe it is love that wrote books and sent us to space.
it is love that saved lives and ended famines.
it is love that helped.
not hate.
and whatever hate burns, love will continue to build,
to heal.
I believe we are better than this.
I believe we have to be, for our future, for each other, for our world,
we have to cross all boundaries, including those built online,
if we are to have a chance,
no matter who we believe is to blame.
we are all the same.
we all suffer.
those are the simplest truths,
from which love stems,
love, not hate for the other.
we are all the same.
we all suffer.
